elements.content: Three new metal–organic materials containing bismuth and pyridine-2,5-dicarboxylate (pydc) have been synthesized by hydro- and solvothermal methods and have been characterized by single crystal X-ray diffraction. Compound 1, Bi(pydc)(Hpydc)(H2O), crystallizes in the space group P21/c (a = 15.4528(10) Å, b = 7.8242(5) Å, c = 12.7421(8) Å, β = 109.463(1)°) and consists of one-dimensional (1D) chains that assemble into a three-dimensional (3D) supramolecular structure via hydrogen bonding in the x-and y-directions. An interesting complex anionic layer structure containing K+ ions and water molecules in the interlayer regions is observed for compound 2, K4Bi(pydc)3(Hpydc)(H2O)3.3, which crystallizes in the space group P1̅ (a = 9.2359(5) Å, b = 9.5854(5) Å, c = 20.1439(10) Å, α = 86.062(1)°, β = 87.645(1)°, γ = 87.729(1)°). This appears to be the first example of a layered anionic bismuth metal–organic structure where the anionic slabs are separated by positively charged counterions in the interlayer region. Compound 3, (DMA+)3Bi(pydc)2(Hpydc)2 (DMA+ = dimethyl ammonium cation), space group P1̅ (a = 9.6953(6) Å, b = 11.7437(7) Å, c = 18.0006(11) Å, α = 73.282(1)°, β = 78.913(1)°, γ = 78.072(1)°), has a 1D supramolecular chain structure that extends along the x-direction that also contains four-connected nodes of anionic bismuth building block similar to compound 2. The photoluminescent properties of compound 1 are discussed.

elements.content: Three new metal−organic materials containing bismuth and pyridine-2,5-dicarboxylate are reported. One of them forms in a unique structure consisting of anionic layers composed of bismuth clusters that are counterbalanced by potassium cations residing in the interlayer spaces.
elements.clean_text: Three new metal-organic materials containing bismuth and pyridine-2,5-dicarboxylate are reported. One of them forms in a unique structure consisting of anionic layers composed of bismuth clusters that are counterbalanced by potassium cations residing in the interlayer spaces.

elements.content: Bismuth-based materials have many potential applications in medicine, catalysis, piezoelectric and/or high dielectric constant materials, as well as in the field of photoluminescence. Bismuth complexes formed from aminopolycarboxylates or polyamino polycarboxylates, for example, have potential as single source precursors for the preparation of bismuth-based ternary oxides due to their significantly lower decomposition temperatures as well as the molecular level control over the product stoichiometry.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Bismuth-based materials have many potential applications in medicine, catalysis, piezoelectric and/or high dielectric constant materials, as well as in the field of photoluminescence. Bismuth complexes formed from aminopolycarboxylates or polyamino polycarboxylates, for example, have potential as single source precursors for the preparation of bismuth-based ternary oxides due to their significantly lower decomposition temperatures as well as the molecular level control over the product stoichiometry.

elements.content: Bismuth-containing metal–organic coordination polymers have been less explored compared to transition metal based complexes, even though main group elements such as bismuth, tin, lead, and antimony coordinate well to alkoxide and/or carboxylic acids. High ligand lability, Lewis acidity, limited solubility at room temperature, and the ability of bismuth centers to expand their coordination sphere may all have contributed to the limited extent of exploration. In addition, many bismuth complexes that are used as reagents in the formation of heterobimetallic complexes are often less reactive than comparable transition metal precursors.
elements.clean_text: Bismuth-containing metal-organic coordination polymers have been less explored compared to transition metal based complexes, even though main group elements such as bismuth, tin, lead, and antimony coordinate well to alkoxide and/or carboxylic acids. High ligand lability, Lewis acidity, limited solubility at room temperature, and the ability of bismuth centers to expand their coordination sphere may all have contributed to the limited extent of exploration. In addition, many bismuth complexes that are used as reagents in the formation of heterobimetallic complexes are often less reactive than comparable transition metal precursors.

elements.content: The Bi(III) cation has a high affinity for both soft (N:) and hard (O:) donor ligands based on Pearson’s hard–soft acid and base theory, an important factor for planning the synthesis of metal organic coordination polymer where typically greater numbers of donor atoms and chelating structures contribute to the overall stability of the product. Additional factors that influence product formation include the charge of the ligand, preorganization of the ligand (from polymeric to monomeric), and the ligand’s steric efficiency in the coordination sphere around the bismuth center, which can result in a more stable complex structure as indicated by the high stability constants of bismuth complexes formed. Certainly, the presence of strong chelating ligands around bismuth, such as amino polycarboxylate, prevents hydrolysis of such Bi(III) complexes, which are usually stable over a wide pH range (1–10).

elements.content: Aromatic dicarboxylic acid based ligands are commonly used in solvothermal syntheses to prepare novel framework materials for potential use in gas storage, magnetic, and luminescent applications. For example, pyridine-2,5-dicarboxylate (pydc) has been reacted with In(III) to create extended structures in which four-connected nodes arrange into a Kagomé lattice. Recently, we reported the reaction of pydc with Bi(III) to form a similar Kagomé lattice motif arranged from similar four-connected nodes. Pydc ligands have also been used for the self-assembly of dinuclear metal carboxylates into paddle-wheel structures, M2(O2CR)4L2 (M = Cu(II) and Mo(II)) that have been used as secondary building units to form porous metal organic frameworks that have potential for gas storage applications. Interestingly, Mori et al. utilized such paddle wheel based structures to form inclusion complexes where linear polyethers were absorbed into the channels of a three-dimensional (3D) porous MOF (host), forming hybrid-functionalized supramolecules assembled through noncovalent interaction. Other compounds with 3D structure have also been reported from pydc ligand.

Interestingly, Mori et al. utilized such paddle wheel based structures to form inclusion complexes where linear polyethers were absorbed into the channels of a three-dimensional (3D) porous MOF (host), forming hybrid-functionalized supramolecules assembled through noncovalent interaction. elements.content: The pydc ligand was also used to create heterometallic structures, chiral structures, several mono- and heteronuclear Cu(II)-based complex and coordination polymers, radical metal complexes, one- and two-dimensional (1D and 2D) coordination polymers, 2D rhombic grid coordination polymer, 1D zigzag chain, and tetranuclear metallamacrocyclic complexes. In this paper we focus on the reaction between the pydc ligand and Bi(III) salts.

In this paper we focus on the reaction between the pydc ligand and Bi(III) salts.

elements.content: It is known that hydrothermal vs conventional aqueous reactions can favor the formation of kinetic over thermodynamic products and, thus, result in the synthesis of many interesting structure types. Utilizing this synthetic approach, we synthesized three new bismuth-pydc containing metal organic materials Bi(pydc)(Hpydc)(H2O) (1), K4Bi(pydc)3(Hpydc)(H2O)3.3 (2), and (DMA+)3Bi(pydc)2(Hpydc)2 (3), and herein we report their synthesis, structural characterization, and the photoluminescence properties for compound 1.

Utilizing this synthetic approach, we synthesized three new bismuth-pydc containing metal organic materials Bi(pydc)(Hpydc)(H2O) (1), K4Bi(pydc)3(Hpydc)(H2O)3.3 (2), and (DMA+)3Bi(pydc)2(Hpydc)2 (3), and herein we report their synthesis, structural characterization, and the photoluminescence properties for compound 1.

elements.content:
All chemicals were of reagent grade and used without further purification. Bi(NO3)3·5H2O (99.999%), pyridine-2,5-dicarboxylic acid (98%), and 4,4′-bipyridine (98%) were purchased from Sigma-Aldrich.

Synthesis of Bi(pydc)(Hpydc)(H<sub>2</sub>O) (<bold>1</bold>)

A mixture of Bi(NO3)3·5H2O (0.24 g, 0.50 mmol), an excess of pyridine-2,5-dicarboxylic acid (H2pydc) (0.25 g, 1.50 mmol) with 4,4′-bipyridine (0.13 g, 0.85 mmol) or KOH (0.11 g, 2.0 mmol) in deionized water (25 mL) was sealed in a Teflon-lined bomb and heated to a temperature of 140 °C for 3 days and then cooled slowly at 0.1 °C/min to room temperature. Colorless, prismatic crystals and white polycrystalline powder of 1 were obtained in quantitative yield based on bismuth. The products were washed with DMF to dissolve and remove any unreacted ligand that might have been left. The final products were isolated by vacuum filtration.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

All chemicals were of reagent grade and used without further purification. Bi(NO3)3⋅5H2O (99.999%), pyridine-2,5-dicarboxylic acid (98%), and 4,4'-bipyridine (98%) were purchased from Sigma-Aldrich.

Synthesis of Bi(pydc)(Hpydc)(H2O) (1)

A mixture of Bi(NO3)3⋅5H2O (0.24 g, 0.50 mmol), an excess of pyridine-2,5-dicarboxylic acid (H2pydc) (0.25 g, 1.50 mmol) with 4,4'-bipyridine (0.13 g, 0.85 mmol) or KOH (0.11 g, 2.0 mmol) in deionized water (25 mL) was sealed in a Teflon-lined bomb and heated to a temperature of 140 °C for 3 days and then cooled slowly at 0.1 °C/min to room temperature. Colorless, prismatic crystals and white polycrystalline powder of 1 were obtained in quantitative yield based on bismuth. The products were washed with DMF to dissolve and remove any unreacted ligand that might have been left. The final products were isolated by vacuum filtration.

elements.content: A mixture of Bi(NO3)3·5H2O (0.15 g, 0.30 mmol), an excess of pyridine-2,5-dicarboxylic acid (H2pydc) (0.25 g, 1.50 mmol) with KOH (0.03 g, 0.60 mmol), in DMF (6 mL) was sealed in a Teflon-lined bomb and heated to a temperature of 100 °C for 3 days and then cooled slowly at 0.1 °C/min to room temperature. Colorless, square pyramidal crystals of 2 (∼40% yield based on bismuth) were obtained. The final products were immersed in fresh DMF to maintain crystal quality.

elements.content: X-ray intensity data from a colorless prismatic crystal (1) were measured at 295(2) K, and a colorless square pyramidal crystal (2) and a colorless irregular chunky crystal (3) were measured at 100(2) K using a Bruker SMART APEX diffractometer (Mo Kα radiation, λ = 0.71073 Å). Raw area detector data frame processing was performed with the SAINT+ and SADABS programs. Final unit cell parameters were determined by least-squares refinement of 5374 (1), 7128 (2), 6105 (3) reflections from the data sets. Direct methods structure solution, difference Fourier calculations, and full-matrix least-squares refinement against F 2 were performed with SHELXTL.
elements.clean_text:
X-ray Crystallography

X-ray intensity data from a colorless prismatic crystal (1) were measured at 295(2) K, and a colorless square pyramidal crystal (2) and a colorless irregular chunky crystal (3) were measured at 100(2) K using a Bruker SMART APEX diffractometer (Mo Kα radiation, λ = 0.71073 Å). Raw area detector data frame processing was performed with the SAINT+ and SADABS programs. Final unit cell parameters were determined by least-squares refinement of 5374 (1), 7128 (2), 6105 (3) reflections from the data sets. Direct methods structure solution, difference Fourier calculations, and full-matrix least-squares refinement against F 2 were performed with SHELXTL.

elements.content: The monoclinic space group P21/c was uniquely determined by the pattern of systematic absences in the intensity data of compound 1. The asymmetric unit consists of one bismuth atom, two independent ligands, and one water molecule. One of the two ligands is monoprotonated; its carboxylic hydrogen (H4A) was clearly located in a difference map. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined with anisotropic displacement parameters. Hydrogen atoms bonded to carbon were placed in geometrically idealized positions and included as riding atoms. The water and carboxylic hydrogens were located in difference maps and refined isotropically with their O–H distances restrained to be similar.

elements.content: Compound 2 crystallizes in the triclinic system. The space group P1̅ was determined by the successful solution and refinement of the structure. The asymmetric unit consists of one [Bi(pydc)3(Hpydc)]4– complex, five potassium ion positions, one fully ordered water molecule, and an additional five fractionally occupied water molecule sites. The noncoordinated oxygen of one carboxylato group (C13, O5, O6) is disordered over two positions. The disorder likely affects the entire group but could be modeled only for O6. Two of the five independent potassium ions (K1, K5) are located on crystallographic inversion centers. K5 is disordered about the inversion center and was modeled with two independent sites K5A/K5B, with total site occupancy constrained to unity. Potassium K4 is disordered over three independent positions K4A-K4C. These three K sites were likewise constrained to sum to full occupancy. The K4 assembly is part of a disordered layer located at z = 0.5 in the unit cell. The remaining electron density in this layer was modeled as oxygen atoms of disordered water molecules. Five sites were refined (O1S–O5S), with occupancies constrained to physically sensible values; that is, atoms closer than the sum of their van der Waals radii were constrained to have total occupancy summing to not more than 100%. Sites O1S/O2S and O4S/O5S are respectively close together and were constrained to full occupancy; O3S was freely refined to a population of 0.30(2). All non-hydrogen atoms were refined with anisotropic displacement parameters except for disordered atoms (isotropic). Hydrogen atoms bonded to carbon were placed in geometrically idealized positions and included as riding atoms. The hydrogen atoms of water molecule O17 were located by difference synthesis and refined isotropically with O–H and H–H distances restrained to 0.85(2) and 1.25(2) Å, respectively. No hydrogen atoms were located or calculated for the disordered water molecules. For electroneutrality, one of the ligands bonded to bismuth must be protonated. A good position for this proton was located near O11. This position is also strongly indicated by the long C21–O11 distance of 1.307(5) Å and by the reasonable hydrogen bonding arrangement. This hydrogen atom was then refined isotropically with a d(O–H) = 0.85(2) Å distance restraint. The largest residual electron density peak of 1.71 e –/Å3 is located 0.76 Å from the bismuth atom.

elements.content: Compound 3 crystallizes in the triclinic system. The space group P1̅ was determined by the successful solution and refinement of the structure. The asymmetric unit consists of one anionic bismuth complex and three dimethylammonium cations. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined with anisotropic displacement parameters. Hydrogen atoms bonded to carbon and nitrogen were placed in geometrically idealized positions and included as riding atoms. Crystal electroneutrality requires that two ligands of the bismuth complex are protonated. Likely positions for two such hydrogen atoms were located in difference maps, bonded to O3 and O11. These positions are strongly indicated by the long carboxylato C–O bond distances of the involved atoms (C7–O3 = 1.292(4) Å, C21–O11 = 1.324(3) Å). Further verification is the reasonable O–H distances and H3A/H11A U iso values obtained upon free refinement of these hydrogen atoms.

elements.content: Ground mixtures of polycrystalline powders and prismatic crystals of 1 were used to collect powder X-ray diffraction patterns using a Rigaku Ultima IV equipped with high speed DTex detector (Cu Kα radiation λ = 1.5418 Å) over the 2θ range of 5–30°, with a step size of 0.02° and a scan speed of 2°/min. The measured patterns of 1 were compared to the diffraction patterns generated by CrystalMaker 8.0. using the respective single crystal data of 1.
elements.clean_text:
Powder X-ray Diffraction

Ground mixtures of polycrystalline powders and prismatic crystals of 1 were used to collect powder X-ray diffraction patterns using a Rigaku Ultima IV equipped with high speed DTex detector (Cu Kα radiation λ = 1.5418 Å) over the 2θ range of 5-30°, with a step size of 0.02° and a scan speed of 2°/min. The measured patterns of 1 were compared to the diffraction patterns generated by CrystalMaker 8.0. using the respective single crystal data of 1.

elements.content: Diffuse-reflectance spectra of ground sample of compound 1 and of as-received H2pydc were obtained using a Perkin-Elmer Lambda 35 UV/vis scanning spectrophotometer equipped with an integrating sphere. The raw data were converted from reflection to absorbance by the use of the Kubelka–Munk function.
elements.clean_text:
UV-Visible Spectrometry

Diffuse-reflectance spectra of ground sample of compound 1 and of as-received H2pydc were obtained using a Perkin-Elmer Lambda 35 UV/vis scanning spectrophotometer equipped with an integrating sphere. The raw data were converted from reflection to absorbance by the use of the Kubelka-Munk function.

elements.content: Excitation and emission spectra of ground sample of compound 1 and of as-received H2pydc were recorded using a PerkinElmer LS 55 Fluorescence spectrometer. In all cases the maximum in the excitation spectrum was used to generate the emission spectrum. Compound 1 was excited at 369 nm and the as-received H2pydc ligand was excited at a wavelength of 390 nm. All measurements were performed at room temperature.
elements.clean_text:
Photoluminescence

Excitation and emission spectra of ground sample of compound 1 and of as-received H2pydc were recorded using a PerkinElmer LS 55 Fluorescence spectrometer. In all cases the maximum in the excitation spectrum was used to generate the emission spectrum. Compound 1 was excited at 369 nm and the as-received H2pydc ligand was excited at a wavelength of 390 nm. All measurements were performed at room temperature.

elements.content: The reactions of pyridine-2,5-dicarboxylic acid with Bi(NO3)3·5H2O under different hydro-/solvothermal conditions resulted in compounds Bi(pydc)(Hpydc)(H2O) (1), K4Bi(pydc)3(Hpydc)(H2O)3.3 (2), and (DMA+)3Bi(pydc)2(Hpydc)2 (3). During the course of the investigation, we explored the use of different solvents, the addition of strong bases, and the importance of the reaction temperature. We found that by changing the temperature from 140 to 100 °C and switching the solvent from water to DMF, we were able to crystallize compound 1 under the former conditions and compound 2 under the latter. Interestingly, swiching from KOH to NaOH while keeping the remaining reaction conditions identical resulted in different products. Compund 2 has potassium ions incorporated into the structure, while compound 3 did not incorporate the sodium ions. Hence, starting with bismuth nitrate and the ligand, three different products were obtained under related, but different, reaction conditions.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Synthesis

The reactions of pyridine-2,5-dicarboxylic acid with Bi(NO3)3⋅5H2O under different hydro-/solvothermal conditions resulted in compounds Bi(pydc)(Hpydc)(H2O) (1), K4Bi(pydc)3(Hpydc)(H2O)3.3 (2), and (DMA+)3Bi(pydc)2(Hpydc)2 (3). During the course of the investigation, we explored the use of different solvents, the addition of strong bases, and the importance of the reaction temperature. We found that by changing the temperature from 140 to 100 °C and switching the solvent from water to DMF, we were able to crystallize compound 1 under the former conditions and compound 2 under the latter. Interestingly, swiching from KOH to NaOH while keeping the remaining reaction conditions identical resulted in different products. Compund 2 has potassium ions incorporated into the structure, while compound 3 did not incorporate the sodium ions. Hence, starting with bismuth nitrate and the ligand, three different products were obtained under related, but different, reaction conditions.

elements.content: Compound 1 forms in quantitative yield (based on bismuth) and is stable to moisture, unlike compounds 2 and 3, which form in lower yields and which readily decompose when exposed to water/moisture. Consequently, compounds 2 and 3 had to be immersed in fresh DMF for storage prior to using them for single crystal X-ray diffraction, and their bulk and photoluminescence properties were not measured. Note that the dimethyl ammonium cation (DMA+) in compound 3 was obtained due to hydrolysis of DMF during the solvothermal reaction. Relevant crystallographic data for the single-crystal structure refinements for 1–3 are found in Table .
elements.clean_text:
Structure Description

Compound 1 forms in quantitative yield (based on bismuth) and is stable to moisture, unlike compounds 2 and 3, which form in lower yields and which readily decompose when exposed to water/moisture. Consequently, compounds 2 and 3 had to be immersed in fresh DMF for storage prior to using them for single crystal X-ray diffraction, and their bulk and photoluminescence properties were not measured. Note that the dimethyl ammonium cation (DMA+) in compound 3 was obtained due to hydrolysis of DMF during the solvothermal reaction. Relevant crystallographic data for the single-crystal structure refinements for 1-3 are found in Table .

Selected interatomic distances and angles are summarized in Tables – for compounds 1–3, respectively.

The asymmetric unit and atom labeling scheme of compound 1, Bi(pydc)(Hpydc)(H2O), is shown in Figure a. The overall structure is derived from the assembly of 1D chains into a 3D supramolecular structure via hydrogen bonding along the crystallographic a-and b-directions. The asymmetric unit of compound 1 consists of one bismuth atom, two independent ligands (one of them is monoprotonated), and a coordinated water molecule. The coordination sphere around the bismuth cation, BiO5N2, is made up of O and N atoms from the pydc2– and Hpydc– ligands and O from the coordinated water that result in a distorted hemidirected polyhedral coordination environment around the bismuth, where the stereochemically active lone pair occupies one of the apexes (Figure b). Such a distorted hemidirected polyhedron has the typical stereochemically active lone pair characteristics: two relatively short Bi–O distances ranging from 2.209(2)–2.251(2) Å and relatively longer Bi–O as well as Bi–N distances ranging from 2.392(2)–2.866(2) Å, listed in Table . The presence of stereochemically active lone pairs is commonly observed in bismuth-based coordination compounds.

elements.content: The extended structure of compound 1 consists of 1D zigzag chains running along the crystallographic c-direction, formed by covalent bonding between the bismuth centers and the surrounding ligands (). In addition, hydrogen bonding between O(9A)–H(9A)---O(7) reinforces the 1D chain formation. Within the zigzag chain, the adjacent bismuth centers are related by 21 symmetry running along the crystallographic c-direction. Mirror images of the zigzag chain perpendicular to the crystallographic c-direction create the overall structure, in which the chains connect into a 3D structure via extensive hydrogen bonding between the monoprotonated ligands, as shown in Figure . H-bonding between O(4A)–H(4A)---O(6) along the x-axis results in the formation of a 2D structure () that is further connected via hydrogen bonding between O(9B)–H(9B)---O(2), , to form the overall 3D framework.
elements.clean_text: The extended structure of compound 1 consists of 1D zigzag chains running along the crystallographic c-direction, formed by covalent bonding between the bismuth centers and the surrounding ligands (). In addition, hydrogen bonding between O(9A)-H(9A)---O(7) reinforces the 1D chain formation. Within the zigzag chain, the adjacent bismuth centers are related by 21 symmetry running along the crystallographic c-direction. Mirror images of the zigzag chain perpendicular to the crystallographic c-direction create the overall structure, in which the chains connect into a 3D structure via extensive hydrogen bonding between the monoprotonated ligands, as shown in Figure . H-bonding between O(4A)-H(4A)---O(6) along the x-axis results in the formation of a 2D structure () that is further connected via hydrogen bonding between O(9B)-H(9B)---O(2), , to form the overall 3D framework.

elements.content: Compound 2, K4Bi(pydc)3(Hpydc)(H2O)3.3, represents an interesting anionic layered structure in which counter cations reside in the interlayer spaces. SEM images of 2 (shown in Figure ), illustrate its pronounced layered morphology. The labeling scheme and asymmetric unit of 2, which consists of one [Bi(pydc)3(Hpydc)]4– complex, five potassium ion positions, one fully ordered water molecule and an additional five fractionally occupied water molecule sites, is depicted in Figure a. The coordination sphere around the bismuth cation, BiO4N4, is made up of O and N atoms from the pydc2– and Hpydc– ligands to form a slightly distorted bicapped octahedral coordination environment, where a small infuence of the stereochemically active lone pair is apparent (Figure b). Bi–O distances in this polyhedra range from 2.338(3)–2.501(3) Å and Bi–N distances range from 2.472(3)–2.704(3) Å.

elements.content: The anionic layer consists of [Bi(pydc2–)3(Hpydc–)]4– complexes, in which three of the pydc2– ligands are in the “upper” position and one Hpydc– ligand is in the “down” position, with respect to the ligand arrangement around the bismuth cation (). Adjacent [Bi(pydc2–)3(Hpydc–)]4– complexes are related by inversion symmetry and are connected via hydrogen bonding (along the crystallographic c-direction) between O11–H11A---O7 as shown in (inset, viewed along the x-direction). Repetition of these hydrogen-bonded clusters along the crystallographic a-and b-direction creates the hydrogen-bonded anonic layer A shown in Figure . These layers stack exactly on top of each other in an A-A fashion. The negative charge of these hydrogen-bonded anionic layers is counterbalanced by potassium cations located between the layers at two different crystallographic z-positions. One position is located in between the hydrogen-bonded layers, that is, at z = 0 (for K2 and K3). The other potassium cations are located in the interlayers of the hydrogen-bonded layers (with d 002 of 10.04 Å), that is, at z = 0.5 (for K1, K3, and K5). Similarly, water molecules (3.30 per formula unit) are also located in those two z-positions (Figure ). shows another view (along the y-direction) of the layered hydrogen-bonded [Bi(pydc2–)3(Hpydc–)]4– clusters counterbalanced by potassium cations along with water molecules.

elements.content: The existence of this type of anionic layer is rare in coordination polymer chemistry, although an anionic cluster based coordination polymer containing cations in the interlayer spaces has been reported by Lachgar and co-workers. To our knowledge, 2 is the first example of Bi-based clusters forming an anionic layer structure with counter cations residing in the interlayer spaces, mimicking the well-known layered perovskites, for example, Dion-Jacobson, KCa2Nb3O10 and Ruddlesden–Popper, K2La2Ti3O10, in which K+ ions are located between negatively charged metal oxide layers. For these layered perovskites, however, the interlayer cations can be ion-exchanged for protons while maintaining structural integrity. Unfortunately in the case of 2, the crystallinity is destroyed when the crystals are exposed to moisture, and hence we were unable to conduct any post reaction structural modifications.

elements.content: The 1D supramolecular structure of compound 3, (DMA+)3Bi(pydc)2(Hpydc)2, has an asymmetric unit that consists of one anionic bismuth complex, [Bi(pydc)2(Hpydc)2]3–, and three dimethylammonium cations (Figure a). Similar to compound 2, the bismuth cation in compound 3 is located in a slightly distorted bicapped octahedral coordination environment, BiO4N4, in which a small effect of the lone pair on the structure asymmetry is observed (Figure b). Bi–O distances in this polyhedra range from 2.362(2)–2.479(2) Å and Bi–N distances range from 2.526(2)–2.610(2) Å.

elements.content: Powder X-ray diffraction can provide phase purity information and, for example, reveal the presence or absence of polymorphs. The purity of compound 1, which forms in quantitative yield (mixed polycrystalline powder and prismatic single crystals), was checked using powder X-ray diffraction. The powder diffraction patterns that were collected on ground mixtures of polycrystalline powder and prismatic crystals of 1 exactly match the calculated patterns based on the single crystal structure are shown in . This demonstrates that the reaction product is single phase, that no additional polymorph is present, and that within detection limits, no unreacted starting material remains in the samples.
elements.clean_text:
Powder X-ray Diffraction

Powder X-ray diffraction can provide phase purity information and, for example, reveal the presence or absence of polymorphs. The purity of compound 1, which forms in quantitative yield (mixed polycrystalline powder and prismatic single crystals), was checked using powder X-ray diffraction. The powder diffraction patterns that were collected on ground mixtures of polycrystalline powder and prismatic crystals of 1 exactly match the calculated patterns based on the single crystal structure are shown in . This demonstrates that the reaction product is single phase, that no additional polymorph is present, and that within detection limits, no unreacted starting material remains in the samples.

elements.content: Luminescent coordination polymers in which the ligand itself is luminescent are of interest for solid-state lighting applications for two reasons. First, an enhancement in the emission intensity is possible, and second, a shift in the emission maxima can be realized when such ligand is incorporated into a framework structure. We have previously reported two “white” light emitting bismuth based phosphors, in which the latter phenomenon is observed.
elements.clean_text:
Photoluminescence

Luminescent coordination polymers in which the ligand itself is luminescent are of interest for solid-state lighting applications for two reasons. First, an enhancement in the emission intensity is possible, and second, a shift in the emission maxima can be realized when such ligand is incorporated into a framework structure. We have previously reported two "white" light emitting bismuth based phosphors, in which the latter phenomenon is observed.

elements.content: The excitation and emission spectra, as well as UV/vis spectra of compound 1 and the as-received H2pydc ligand, are shown in Figures , and respectively. The as-received H2pydc ligand emits pale-green light with an emission maximum around 518 nm when excited at 390 nm (Figure ). Such emission is likely due to an intraligand π → π* and/or n → π* transition. Compound 1 when excited at 369 nm emits green light with a maximum peak at 533 nm and a broad shoulder at 570 nm (Figure ). The emission spectrum of compound 1 is slightly red-shifted in comparison to that of the as-received H2pydc ligand itself. The UV/vis spectrum of compound 1 () exhibits a maximum absorbance and a shoulder at 315 and 253 nm, respectively, representing a slight shift from the as-received ligand itself, whose maximum peak and shoulder positions are at 304 and 257 nm, respectively, and the disappearance of broad shoulder at 435 nm in compound 1 spectra. This type of an emission shift has been observed in other metal organic materials.

elements.content: Three new metal organic hybrid structures containing bismuth and pyridine-2,5-dicarboxylate are reported. Compound 1, which displays green light emission, is a 1D coordination polymers connected into a 3D structure via hydrogen bonding. An interesting anionic layer of bismuth clusters counterbalanced by potassium ions that reside in the interlayer spaces is observed for compound 2. Compound 3 is a 1D supramolecular compound built-up from hydrogen-bonded anionic bismuth complexes, counterbalanced by dimethyl ammonium cations that are located in the lattice. Compounds 2 and 3 display similar bismuth coordination environments in which very little indication of a stereochemically active lone pair of bismuth is evident. In both structures anionic building blocks are counterbalanced by cations, either readily available from the solvothermal solution (compound 2) or formed in situ (compound 3).
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

Three new metal organic hybrid structures containing bismuth and pyridine-2,5-dicarboxylate are reported. Compound 1, which displays green light emission, is a 1D coordination polymers connected into a 3D structure via hydrogen bonding. An interesting anionic layer of bismuth clusters counterbalanced by potassium ions that reside in the interlayer spaces is observed for compound 2. Compound 3 is a 1D supramolecular compound built-up from hydrogen-bonded anionic bismuth complexes, counterbalanced by dimethyl ammonium cations that are located in the lattice. Compounds 2 and 3 display similar bismuth coordination environments in which very little indication of a stereochemically active lone pair of bismuth is evident. In both structures anionic building blocks are counterbalanced by cations, either readily available from the solvothermal solution (compound 2) or formed in situ (compound 3).

All chemicals were of reagent grade and used without further purification. Bi(NO3)3·5H2O (99.999%), pyridine-2,5-dicarboxylic acid (98%), and 4,4′-bipyridine (98%) were purchased from Sigma-Aldrich.

Synthesis of Bi(pydc)(Hpydc)(H<sub>2</sub>O) (<bold>1</bold>)

A mixture of Bi(NO3)3·5H2O (0.24 g, 0.50 mmol), an excess of pyridine-2,5-dicarboxylic acid (H2pydc) (0.25 g, 1.50 mmol) with 4,4′-bipyridine (0.13 g, 0.85 mmol) or KOH (0.11 g, 2.0 mmol) in deionized water (25 mL) was sealed in a Teflon-lined bomb and heated to a temperature of 140 °C for 3 days and then cooled slowly at 0.1 °C/min to room temperature. Colorless, prismatic crystals and white polycrystalline powder of 1 were obtained in quantitative yield based on bismuth. The products were washed with DMF to dissolve and remove any unreacted ligand that might have been left. The final products were isolated by vacuum filtration.

Synthesis of K<sub>4</sub>Bi(pydc)<sub>3</sub>(Hpydc)(H<sub>2</sub>O)<sub>3.3</sub> (<bold>2</bold>)

A mixture of Bi(NO3)3·5H2O (0.15 g, 0.30 mmol), an excess of pyridine-2,5-dicarboxylic acid (H2pydc) (0.25 g, 1.50 mmol) with KOH (0.03 g, 0.60 mmol), in DMF (6 mL) was sealed in a Teflon-lined bomb and heated to a temperature of 100 °C for 3 days and then cooled slowly at 0.1 °C/min to room temperature. Colorless, square pyramidal crystals of 2 (∼40% yield based on bismuth) were obtained. The final products were immersed in fresh DMF to maintain crystal quality.

Synthesis of (DMA<sup>+</sup>)<sub>3</sub>Bi(pydc)<sub>2</sub>(Hpydc)<sub>2</sub> (<bold>3</bold>)

A mixture of Bi(NO3)3·5H2O (0.15 g, 0.30 mmol), an excess of pyridine-2,5-dicarboxylic acid (H2pydc) (0.25 g, 1.50 mmol) with NaOH (0.02 g, 0.60 mmol), in DMF (6 mL) was sealed in a Teflon-lined bomb and heated to a temperature of 100 °C for 3 days and then cooled slowly at 0.1 °C/min to room temperature. Colorless, irregular chunky crystals of 3 (∼40% yield based on bismuth) were obtained. The final products were immersed in fresh DMF to maintain crystal quality.

cln_elements.content: Three new metal–organic materials containing bismuth and pyridine-2,5-dicarboxylate (pydc) have been synthesized by hydro- and solvothermal methods and have been characterized by single crystal X-ray diffraction. Compound 1, Bi(pydc)(Hpydc)(H2O), crystallizes in the space group P21/c (a = 15.4528(10) Å, b = 7.8242(5) Å, c = 12.7421(8) Å, β = 109.463(1)°) and consists of one-dimensional (1D) chains that assemble into a three-dimensional (3D) supramolecular structure via hydrogen bonding in the x-and y-directions. An interesting complex anionic layer structure containing K+ ions and water molecules in the interlayer regions is observed for compound 2, K4Bi(pydc)3(Hpydc)(H2O)3.3, which crystallizes in the space group P1̅ (a = 9.2359(5) Å, b = 9.5854(5) Å, c = 20.1439(10) Å, α = 86.062(1)°, β = 87.645(1)°, γ = 87.729(1)°). This appears to be the first example of a layered anionic bismuth metal–organic structure where the anionic slabs are separated by positively charged counterions in the interlayer region. Compound 3, (DMA+)3Bi(pydc)2(Hpydc)2 (DMA+ = dimethyl ammonium cation), space group P1̅ (a = 9.6953(6) Å, b = 11.7437(7) Å, c = 18.0006(11) Å, α = 73.282(1)°, β = 78.913(1)°, γ = 78.072(1)°), has a 1D supramolecular chain structure that extends along the x-direction that also contains four-connected nodes of anionic bismuth building block similar to compound 2. The photoluminescent properties of compound 1 are discussed.
